author: By Maya Phillips
title: Finding More Than Humbug in Scrooge and Company
description: “A Christmas Carol” is a favorite of Maya Phillips, but this year, she writes, she found in it “a timely study of what it truly means to be a decent person in a community.”
content: When I was younger, I drank in every version of “A Christmas Carol” I could find like they were tumblers of eggnog. Eventually, I became a connoisseur. (I maintain the supremacy of “The Muppet Christmas Carol” and “Scrooged,” which I am obligated to watch whenever they’re on TV.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: The Essential John le Carré
description: The novelist transformed moral ambiguity and the lives of Cold War spies into high art. If you’ve never read any of his thrillers, here are seven we recommend.
content: John le Carré, who died over the weekend at age 89, left behind a remarkable literary legacy. He wrote 25 novels over nearly six decades, zeroing in on the machinations of the espionage community and distilling complex interior conflicts into eminently readable tales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne and Michael Gonchar
title: Do You Want Your Parents and Grandparents to Get the New Coronavirus Vaccine?
description: A vaccine against Covid-19 has begun to be distributed in the United States. Do you plan on getting vaccinated? Do you want your loved ones and friends to get the vaccine?
content: On Dec. 11, the Food and Drug Administration authorized Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use, clearing the way for millions of highly vulnerable people to begin receiving the vaccine within days. Early this month the United Kingdom and Canada approved the vaccine as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Google Dominates Thanks to an Unrivaled View of the Web
description: As regulators seek ways to curb the company’s power, there is more focus on the vast index — hundreds of billions of web pages — behind its search engine.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — In 2000, just two years after it was founded, Google reached a milestone that would lay the foundation for its dominance over the next 20 years: It became the world’s largest search engine, with an index of more than one billion web pages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: China’s Combative Nationalists See a World Turning Their Way
description: China’s Communist Party is pushing the narrative that the pandemic has proved the superiority of its authoritarian model. The muscular message is finding fans at home.
content: In one Beijing artist’s recent depiction of the world in 2098, China is a high-tech superpower and the United States is humbled. Americans have embraced communism and Manhattan, draped with the hammer-and-sickle flags of the “People’s Union of America,” has become a quaint tourist precinct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: N.C.A.A. Will Hold 2021 Women’s Basketball Tournament in One Region
description: The N.C.A.A. announced that it was in preliminary talks with officials in and around San Antonio to host the entire 63-game tournament in the spring.
content: The 2021 N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament will be held in one region in hopes that reduced travel will limit the spread of the coronavirus across the 64 teams expected to play, the Division I Women’s Basketball Committee announced Monday, mirroring the format set last month for the men’s competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Young Kim Discusses the California G.O.P., After Trump
description: Monday: The representative-elect discusses the state’s pandemic response and the future of the Republican Party: “This is not a Trump or Biden issue.”
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: U.K. to Ease Rules on Blood Donations by Gay and Bisexual Men
description: The new policy, which will take effect next summer, was described by Britain’s health secretary as a landmark and by an activist as “a fundamental shift toward recognizing people are individuals.”
content: Britain announced on Monday that it would loosen restrictions on blood donation by gay and bisexual men beginning next year, a shift in policy called “landmark” by the government and hailed by activists who have long fought rules they described as discriminatory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon
title: The number of people with the virus who died in the U.S. passes 300,000.
description: The number of people with the coronavirus in the United States who have died passed 300,000 on Monday, another wrenching record that comes less than four weeks after the nation’s virus deaths reached a quarter-million.
content: The number of people with the coronavirus in the United States who have died passed 300,000 on Monday, another wrenching record that comes less than four weeks after the nation’s virus deaths reached a quarter-million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Perez Hilton vs. the Fan Armies
description: The celebrity blogger was banned from TikTok on Saturday in a move he said was influenced by the app’s biggest stars.
content: Perez Hilton, the early gossip blogger turned media personality, has been permanently banned from TikTok for violating community guidelines, effective Dec. 12.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Hearing Aids Could Use Some Help
description: The vital medical devices could be inexpensive and available over the counter. But efforts have stalled under the F.D.A.
content: By now, we were supposed to be swiftly approaching the day when we could walk into a CVS or Walgreens, a Best Buy or Walmart, and walk out with a pair of quality, affordable hearing aids approved by the Food and Drug Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Claims of ‘Bleak’ Environmental Justice Record Appear to Fell a Biden Favorite
description: The president-elect’s transition team is scrambling to find a new candidate for the E.P.A. after advocates objected to Mary D. Nichols.
content: WASHINGTON — When Joseph R. Biden, Jr. won the presidential election, his top candidate to lead the nation’s most powerful environmental agency appeared clear: Mary D. Nichols, California’s clean air regulator and arguably the country’s most experienced climate change official, was seen as a lock to run the Environmental Protection Agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember, Kathleen Gray and Glenn Thrush
title: Michigan Republican leaders affirm state’s electoral votes and reprimand lawmaker who suggested there might be violence.
description: The two most senior leaders in the Michigan legislature, both Republicans, on Monday affirmed the state’s electoral votes that would formalize Joseph R. Biden’s victory, as a fellow lawmaker was punished for suggesting there may be violence at the meeting of electors.
content: The two most senior leaders in the Michigan legislature, both Republicans, on Monday affirmed the state’s electoral votes that would formalize Joseph R. Biden’s victory, as a fellow lawmaker was punished for suggesting there may be violence at the meeting of electors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: 9 Great John le Carré Adaptations to Stream
description: From the beginning, his novels of Cold War espionage and moral ambiguity attracted leading actors and filmmakers. Here are nine that can be streamed.
content: Few authors have had a better shake at the movies than John le Carré, whose sophisticated novels of Cold War atmosphere, moral ambiguities and wryly observed backroom machinations have long attracted talented filmmakers and leading actors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.5 Million Homes in California
description: A new three-bedroom house in Los Angeles, a Shingle-style home in Inverness and a Mediterranean retreat in Santa Barbara.
content: The Silver Lake section of Los Angeles was developed in the early 20th century around Silver Lake Reservoir, a man-made lake about a mile from this house. The reservoir remains a center of neighborhood life, surrounded by walking trails, a dog park and a recreation center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri, Melissa Kravitz Hoeffner, Nate Schweber, Alexandra E. Petri, J. David Goodman and Jesse McKinley
title: New York City restaurants brace for a brutal winter.
description: A surge in coronavirus infections prompted Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to announce a ban on indoor dining in New York City restaurants, which went into effect on Monday. Now, thousands of restaurants face an uncertain future as they brace for brutal winter months that could reduce business to new lows.
content: A surge in coronavirus infections prompted Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to announce a ban on indoor dining in New York City restaurants, which went into effect on Monday. Now, thousands of restaurants face an uncertain future as they brace for brutal winter months that could reduce business to new lows.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The U.S. Approves a Vaccine
description: An initial shipment of about 2.9 million doses of Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine will be sent around the United States over the next week. So what happens next?
content: The Food and Drug Administration authorized Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use on Friday, clearing the way for millions of highly vulnerable people to begin receiving inoculations within days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: In Canada, the First Vaccines Leave Health Workers in Tears of Relief
description: “We were desperate.” As nursing home employees received the first vaccinations on Monday, memories of the pandemic’s first wave left some overwhelmed with emotion.
content: TORONTO — During the applause, the celebratory elbow bumps, the camera flashes, Colette Cameron watched through tears as four of her colleagues got jabbed Monday with the country’s first coronavirus vaccinations. Then she removed her suit jacket to follow them herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Books Are Really Easy to Wrap
description: But that’s not why they make the best gifts.
content: NASHVILLE — Once upon a time, not all that long ago, the word “Zoom” meant nothing more to me than the name of an old kids’ show on public television or the punchline of a commercial for fast cars. “Google Hangouts” sounded like something only teenagers needed to know about, and “Microsoft Teams,” if I had to guess, was some kind of technical support department requiring an hour on hold to reach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: With Americans Stuck at Home, Trade With China Roars Back
description: Reducing trade with China was supposed to happen in 2020. But demand for Chinese goods has soared amid pandemic lockdowns.
content: WASHINGTON — American imports from China are surging as the year draws to a close, fueled by stay-at-home shoppers who are snapping up Chinese-made furniture and appliances, along with Barbie Dream Houses and bicycles for the holidays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Representative Paul Mitchell leaves Republican Party over its refusal to accept Trump’s loss.
description: Representative Paul Mitchell of Michigan, a two-term Republican who voted for President Trump this year, announced on Monday that he would immediately sever his ties with the Republican Party over its refusal to accept the president’s election defeat.
content: Representative Paul Mitchell of Michigan, a two-term Republican who voted for President Trump this year, announced on Monday that he would immediately sever his ties with the Republican Party over its refusal to accept the president’s election defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein, Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
title: 5 Highlights of the N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race: Yang and Rose Enter
description: As Kathryn Garcia and Shaun Donovan officially launched their campaigns last week, two newcomers, Andrew Yang and Rep. Max Rose, seemed poised to soon join them.
content: One of the traditions of modern-day election cycles is the two-step dance that candidates perform in launching their campaigns. First comes the string of obvious clues: a listening tour, speeches delivered at Sunday church, and perhaps even an announcement of an exploratory bid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Gammon
title: The Psychic Toll of a Pandemic Pregnancy
description: Women who had Covid while expecting experienced guilt, shame and unhealthy levels of stress.
content: Kate Glaser had chalked up her exhaustion to being 39 weeks pregnant and having twin toddlers in the house. She also wondered whether her flulike symptoms were a sign that she was about to go into labor. But when she woke up one morning with a 100.4-degree fever, she called her doctor and got a rapid Covid-19 test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kerry Hannon
title: It’s a Terrible Time for Small Businesses. Except When It’s Not.
description: Some entrepreneurs are finding opportunities in unlikely places.
content: A counterintuitive silver lining to the pandemic is developing: While droves of small businesses across the United States have been crushed by Covid-19 and its restrictions, others have been pushed to lift off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: A World of Cardsharps and Zoom Dupes in ‘The Future’
description: In his latest magic show, Helder Guimarães shuffles an old genre into a new technology with mixed results.
content: When a used-car salesman says, “I will be honest,” it’s a sure sign he won’t be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Russell Wilson Throws Four Touchdowns in Three Quarters in Win Over the Jets
description: The Seahawks rebounded from a loss to the Giants last week, while the Jets’ losing streak reached a franchise record 13 games.
content: SEATTLE (AP) — Russell Wilson threw four touchdowns passes to give him a new career-high with 36 for the season before resting in the fourth quarter, leading the Seattle Seahawks to a 40-3 rout of the Jets on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Pinterest Settles Gender Discrimination Suit for $22.5 Million
description: The suit had been brought by Françoise Brougher, Pinterest’s former chief operating officer, who said she was fired after speaking up about mistreatment.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Pinterest on Monday agreed to pay $22.5 million to settle a gender discrimination and retaliation lawsuit from Françoise Brougher, its former chief operating officer, in one of the largest publicly announced individual settlements for gender discrimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tala Schlossberg
title: An Ode to the Before Times
description: Also, I think I’m losing my mind.
content: We all miss things that used to be normal — hugging friends, dancing in crowded places, not being terrified of standing near someone with a dry cough. But what about everything else that we took for granted? After nearly a year of social distancing, a new normal is starting to settle into place, and memories of how things used to be are only growing hazier. When we finally emerge on the other side of all this — hopefully with our sanity loosely intact — will we come to miss this strange year, too?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Tech I.P.O.s Take a Breather
description: Roblox delayed its debut as Wall Street worries about a bubble.
content: The eye-popping stock market debuts of Airbnb and DoorDash last week have led to the delay of at least one eagerly awaited I.P.O., as executives are taken aback by the strength of the tech stock craze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Al Bello
title: A Gym Is Where You Work Out. Everything Else Is Optional.
description: Forced to close its physical location because of the pandemic, a Long Island gym has adapted to its members’ settings and abilities, creating an entirely new type of fitness community.
content: In March 2014, Dennis Guerrero and his business partner opened a gym on Long Island. The pair shared a passion for fitness, a dream of creating a community of like-minded people and a willingness to take a risk. Over the next six years, hundreds of members experienced and embraced an environment that fostered a palpable energy, helping athletes of all ages and abilities reach their potential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Bills Beat the Steelers, Surging as a Rival Sinks
description: Buffalo can clinch the A.F.C. East title on Saturday. Pittsburgh fell behind Kansas City in the race for the top seed in the playoffs.
content: After the interception that cemented Buffalo’s standing among the N.F.L. elite, the Bills’ defense assembled and jogged the remaining length of the field together, toward the end zone and the cameras and oceans of blue seats. It was midway through the fourth quarter Sunday on a night at Bills Stadium that begged for fans, dancing in the aisles to “Shout” and swilling their Labatts and celebrating a victory that reverberated far beyond western New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: To quash vaccine misinformation, this doctor opts for facts over fighting fiction.
description: The coronavirus vaccinations are starting. Now Americans need to be persuaded to trust and accept them.
content: The coronavirus vaccinations are starting. Now Americans need to be persuaded to trust and accept them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dashiell Young-Saver
title: What Does 95% Effective Mean? Teaching the Math of Vaccine Efficacy
description: In this lesson plan, students use statistics, probability and math to understand how big a breakthrough the new coronavirus vaccine is and what it might mean for the pandemic.
content: Featured article: “2 Companies Say Their Vaccines Are 95% Effective. What Does That Mean?” by Carl Zimmer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden calls Trump’s attacks on voting ‘unconscionable.’
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Monday denounced the attacks on voting by President Trump and his allies, calling them “unconscionable” and saying that no officials should ever face the kind of pressure they received to falsely proclaim an election to be fraudulent.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Monday denounced the attacks on voting by President Trump and his allies, calling them “unconscionable” and saying that no officials should ever face the kind of pressure they received to falsely proclaim an election to be fraudulent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Putu Sayoga
title: In Indonesia, a Blurred Boundary Between the Living and the Dead
description: The Toraja people of southern Sulawesi, one of Indonesia’s largest islands, are known for their elaborate death rituals, which include preserving and exhuming the dead.
content: Editor’s note: This photo essay contains images of human remains that may disturb some readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Can Congress Overturn the Electoral College Results? Probably Not
description: Republicans are planning one final showdown. They are almost certain to fail, but not before Vice President Mike Pence is thrust into having to declare President Trump the loser.
content: The Electoral College’s certification on Monday of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory left just one final venue for President Trump and his supporters to challenge the results of the 2020 election: a joint session of Congress in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The Next Vaccine Challenge: Reassuring Older Americans
description: The two leading coronavirus vaccines seemed to work well in elderly trial volunteers. “I just can’t understand why people are afraid,” one 95-year-old said.
content: He can barely see or hear, but 95-year-old Frank Bruno lives on his own terms: alone, unafraid and now — thanks to the coronavirus vaccine — “ironclad,” as he describes it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough
title: Did You Get the Coronavirus Vaccine, or Are You Planning To?
description: The New York Times would like to hear from people in the U.S. who received a vaccination against Covid-19, or hoped to get one.
content: With approval from the Food and Drug Administration now in hand, Pfizer is shipping doses of its coronavirus vaccine this week to hospitals around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Weiner
title: How Do We Get to Herd Immunity for Fake News?
description: We need to match our focus on the supply of misinformation with a focus on the demand for it.
content: Last week, veto-proof majorities of the House and Senate rejected President Trump’s demand that they use a defense-spending bill to repeal liability protections for social media companies. The demand arose from Mr. Trump’s frustration with platforms like Twitter for taking more assertive measures against misinformation and disinformation, including his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Introduction to ‘Current Events Conversations’
description: Want to learn more about this feature? Watch this short introduction video on our weekly roundup of student conversations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: After a Covid-19 Semester, College Doctors Reflect on Sports
description: Weighing the risks and benefits of participating in sports against the larger public health factors.
content: My latest column, about the American Academy of Pediatrics’ new guidance on youth sports in the time of Covid, drew two very different sets of parental responses. The guidance emphasizes the importance of wearing face coverings, and also the importance of making sure that any young athletes who have had Covid infections — even asymptomatic infections — are checked out medically before they return, gradually, to full activity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinne Purtill
title: How Climate Policy Will Change in 2021
description: A group of experts gathered to debate the prospects for the new White House administration’s big promises on the environment.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. made action on climate change a central part of his platform during the election campaign, promising a $1.7 trillion investment in clean energy and environmental justice, net-zero emissions in the United States by 2050 and an immediate return to the Paris Agreement. He has reportedly raised the issue of climate in every congratulatory call he has accepted from world leaders, and he has pledged to make climate a focus in every federal agency so that the issue doesn’t end up sidelined in the daily grind of governance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Sudan Celebrates ‘New Era’ as U.S. Drops It From Terrorism List
description: The Trump administration formally removed the country from a list of state sponsors of terrorism on Monday, ending nearly three decades of international isolation.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Sudan took a major step back into the international fold on Monday when the United States formally removed it from a list of nations that sponsor terrorism, ending a 27-year period of isolation that left the vast African country a diplomatic pariah, hobbled its economy and blocked access to financial aid that it now urgently needs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucia Walinchus and Richard A. Oppel Jr
title: Conflicting Narratives Emerge in Ohio Shooting, Prompting Protests
description: Much about the shooting death of Casey Goodson Jr. by a sheriff’s deputy has been disputed — what led to it, why it happened and where exactly on his body Mr. Goodson was shot.
content: COLUMBUS, Ohio — In the moment before Casey Goodson Jr. was shot dead by a sheriff’s deputy at the entrance of his home, his lifelong neighbor heard a man shouting, as if he were arguing, and then a burst of gunfire.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Watch live: Electors to vote in Pennsylvania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Germany prepares for a lockdown.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Storm May Bring Over 6 Inches of Snow From Virginia to New England
description: Some areas north and west of the Interstate 95 corridor in New Jersey and Pennsylvania may get more than a foot of snow on Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.
content: A storm is expected to bring more than six inches of snow from Virginia to New England on Wednesday, with the potential to cause widespread power loss and hamper travel across a large section of the country, according to the National Weather Service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Loewenstein and Cynthia Cryder
title: Why Paying People to Be Vaccinated Could Backfire
description: Some economists and politicians have proposed offering financial incentives, but that risks sending an unintended message.
content: The approval of the first Covid-19 vaccine in the United States was hailed over the weekend as the beginning of the end of the pandemic. But the road between delivering the first doses and widespread vaccination at rates that will arrest the spread of coronavirus is far from straightforward. Besides the logistical challenges of distributing the vaccine, people must also be willing to take it. As recently as late November, 37 percent of Americans indicated they would not be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: This ‘Nutcracker’ Is a Fantasy You Can Enter
description: Troy Schumacher’s immersive “The Nutcracker at Wethersfield” provides a dreamlike experience.
content: You may have seen the ballet “The Nutcracker” countless times. Watching it every year might be a holiday tradition. But have you ever been inside it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Joseph Goldstein
title: 1st Vaccination in U.S. Is Given in New York, Hard Hit in Outbreak’s First Days
description: A nurse in Queens received the coronavirus vaccine during a news conference with Gov. Andrew Cuomo.
content: The first coronavirus vaccination in the United States took place on Monday morning in Queens, state officials said, signaling a turning point in the battle against a pandemic that has profoundly scarred New York, killing more than 35,000 people and severely weakening the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Google Delays Return to Office and Eyes ‘Flexible Work Week’
description: The Silicon Valley company now plans to have employees return to the office in September. It will be different when they get there.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — With the pandemic still in full swing and the first doses of a coronavirus vaccine just starting to ship in the United States, Google has pushed back the planned return to the office by a few months, to September 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Jannat Batra
title: Early Voting Begins in Georgia for High-Stakes Senate Runoffs
description: Across the state, roadside signs urge residents to vote one more time. On Monday, many did, as both of the state’s G.O.P. senators face Democratic challengers.
content: ATLANTA — For weeks, the runoff races for Georgia’s two Senate seats have virtually been impossible for residents to escape, as campaign coverage has dominated the local news and advertisements praising or attacking the candidates have filled every commercial break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: Kaatsbaan Announces Spring Festival
description: The Hudson Valley arts organization expands its outdoor dance festival to include concerts and panels at its 153 acre campus in Tivoli, N.Y., in May.
content: American Ballet Theater, Mark Morris Dance Group and dancers from New York City Ballet and Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will headline Kaatsbaan Cultural Park’s follow up to its successful inaugural performance festival last summer. Kaatsbaan, which occupies 153 acres in Tivoli, N.Y., will present outdoor performances, concerts and panels in May, the arts organization announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Art of Political Murder’ and CBS Specials
description: A documentary about the murder of the Guatemalan bishop Juan José Gerardi debuts on HBO. And two celebrity benefit shows air on CBS.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Dec. 14-20. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Norman Pearlstine, Top Editor of Los Angeles Times, Takes Adviser Role
description: The veteran journalist took charge of the newsroom two years ago in an effort to bring stability to the paper under new ownership.
content: Norman Pearlstine, the executive editor of The Los Angeles Times, has moved into a senior adviser role while the search for his successor continues, the paper’s owner said in an email to the staff on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: When Did Republicans Start Hating Facts?
description: A straight line runs from Reagan to the Trump dead-enders.
content: Republicans spent most of 2020 rejecting science in the face of a runaway pandemic; now they’re rejecting democracy in the face of a clear election loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: John le Carré, a Master of Spy Novels Where the Real Action Was Internal
description: The author, who died on Saturday, “had a knack for language of every variety,” our critic Dwight Garner writes. “His books hum with the flavorful and recondite language of espionage.”
content: George Orwell wrote that a creative writer can expect to remain at the top of his form for only about 15 years. John le Carré wrote espionage novels at a high level for nearly 60. His first, “Call for the Dead,” was published in 1961; his last, “Agent Running in the Field,” appeared just last year. There were mediocre books in between, but surprisingly few of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: William Barr Is Out as Attorney General
description: Mr. Barr was one of the most powerful members of President Trump’s cabinet and faced widespread criticism over his willingness to advance Mr. Trump’s political agenda.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Monday that Attorney General William P. Barr would depart next week, ending a tenure marked by Mr. Barr’s willingness to advance the president’s political agenda and by criticism that he eroded the post-Watergate independence of the Justice Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Adam Nagourney
title: 4 Takeaways From Biden’s Electoral College Victory
description: Joe Biden was confirmed as the winner of the election, but President Trump’s war on the results is likely to have lasting effects for the country.
content: Some electors received police escorts. Some cast their votes in an undisclosed location. Some drew a nationwide audience for what is usually a procedural and obscure constitutional undertaking. Most wore masks and adhered to social distancing rules in deference to the coronavirus pandemic that has defined this long campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Mikaela Shiffrin Wins First World Cup Race Since January
description: Shiffrin’s 67th victory places her third on the career list and comes 10 months after the death of her father, Jeff.
content: Calling the victory bittersweet, Mikaela Shiffrin, the two-time Olympic champion, won a World Cup giant slalom on Monday in Courchevel, France, her first time atop an Alpine podium since the accidental death of her father, Jeff, 10 months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: What’s Next for Trump Voters Who Believe the Election Was Stolen?
description: Some are certain the election was fraudulent. Others aren’t so sure. What becomes of their skepticism has important implications for American democracy.
content: WASHINGTON — Richard Everit walked with a heavy heart from his hotel to join a rally being held by President Trump’s supporters near the White House on Saturday morning. The Supreme Court had rejected a lawsuit by Texas the night before, extinguishing what little hope he had left for the re-election of Mr. Trump, the man who had inspired the first vote of his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Leslie-Lohman Museum Announces New Director
description: The nonprofit executive Alyssa Nitchun will lead the museum after its last director, Gonzalo Casals, became the Cultural Affairs Commissioner of New York City.
content: The question of who should steer the Leslie-Lohman Museum of Art through the coronavirus pandemic and toward a new chapter in its 50-year history of championing queer art was answered Monday when the board announced it had selected the nonprofit executive Alyssa Nitchun to become its next director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Just When Restaurants Thought 2020 Couldn’t Get Any Worse …
description: Everything seemed to conspire against New York City’s food and drink businesses. Now, indoor dining has been taken away again.
content: Most New York City restaurants, if they followed the rules and adapted to the pandemic, have been able to serve seated customers for a total of about nine months this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: In many Covid-19 obituaries, personal details are accompanied by virus pleas.
description: By Sunday, deaths from the coronavirus were approaching 300,000 in the United States, a toll comparable to losing the entire population of Pittsburgh or St. Louis. Reports of new deaths have more than doubled in the last month to an average of nearly 2,400 each day, more than at any other point in the pandemic.
content: By Sunday, deaths from the coronavirus were approaching 300,000 in the United States, a toll comparable to losing the entire population of Pittsburgh or St. Louis. Reports of new deaths have more than doubled in the last month to an average of nearly 2,400 each day, more than at any other point in the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A Raging Pandemic Inspires Poetry With Little Bite
description: “Together in a Sudden Strangeness,” edited by Alice Quinn, gathers poems that react to life during the coronavirus crisis.
content: What are poets for? One answer arrives in Salman Rushdie’s novel “The Satanic Verses,” when the satirical poet Baal comments that “a poet’s work” is “to name the unnamable, to point at frauds, to take sides, start arguments, shape the world and stop it from going to sleep.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimon de Greef
title: New Arrests in Killing of White South African Farmer
description: A case that made headlines because of perceived racial overtones has taken on new implications after the arrest of the victim’s wife.
content: The murder attracted global attention: A white South African farmer was shot dead in his home last year, not long after seeing his vineyards invaded by shack dwellers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Jim Rutenberg
title: The Electoral College votes in key battleground states for Biden without any surprises or defections.
description: The Electoral College was nearing completion Monday afternoon of the process that will officially designate Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the president-elect, as electors in battleground states President Trump had contested — Pennsylvania, Michigan, Wisconsin, Georgia and Arizona — voted with no surprises or defections.
content: The Electoral College was nearing completion Monday afternoon of the process that will officially designate Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the president-elect, as electors in battleground states President Trump had contested — Pennsylvania, Michigan, Wisconsin, Georgia and Arizona — voted with no surprises or defections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Turkey Over 2017 Purchase of Russian Missile Defenses
description: Trump had resisted the economic penalties against Turkey in favor of his personal relationship with President
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration issued sanctions against Turkey’s military acquisitions agency on Monday to punish the NATO ally more than three years after it bought a missile defense system from Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The first vaccine reached New York on Monday at a fraught moment in the state.
description: The first coronavirus vaccines have arrived in New York at a time of urgency, with the virus regaining a foothold in a state that it has profoundly scarred, killing more than 35,000 people and severely weakening the economy.
content: The first coronavirus vaccines have arrived in New York at a time of urgency, with the virus regaining a foothold in a state that it has profoundly scarred, killing more than 35,000 people and severely weakening the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Cyberpunk 2077 Developer Apologizes and Offers Refund for Game Glitches
description: The company behind the long-awaited video game pledged to fix the bugs and crashes after complaints from players poured in over the weekend.
content: The maker behind Cyberpunk 2077, one of the year’s most highly anticipated video games, on Monday apologized and offered refunds to players who were disappointed in the game’s performance, after days of complaints over glitches and poor visuals on some platforms following its release last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: As U.S. Deaths Surpass 300,000, Obituaries Force Reckoning with Covid
description: Families of some who perished have written pointedly about the virus in remembrances. They tell of agonizing final days. They plead for wearing of masks.
content: CHICAGO — When Kim Miller sat down in her Illinois house to compose her husband’s obituary, she could not hold back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: How the Bee Gees Stayed Alive
description: The HBO documentary “The Bee Gees: How Can You Mend a Broken Heart” traces the decades-long arc of a band that mastered a rare pop skill: adaptation.
content: Discovered, embraced, disbanded, reunited, ignored, reinvented, hailed, scorned, disguised, recognized — the Bee Gees’ long career was filled with improbable ups and downs. Most bands are lucky to get one Top 10 hitmaking streak. The Bee Gees — the brothers Barry, Robin and Maurice Gibb — had at least two, singing heartache ballads in the late 1960s and re-emerging in the mid-1970s as the multiplatinum pop face of disco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: A new study shows an arthritis drug may help Covid-19 patients recover.
description: Adding an arthritis drug called baricitinib to Covid-19 treatment regimens that include the antiviral drug remdesivir might shave a day or more off recovery times, especially for those who are seriously sick, according to a study published on Friday.
content: Adding an arthritis drug called baricitinib to Covid-19 treatment regimens that include the antiviral drug remdesivir might shave a day or more off recovery times, especially for those who are seriously sick, according to a study published on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Social Isolation May Increase Your Risk of Falls
description: People who lived alone or who had few social contacts were up to 24 percent more likely to have falls than their socially connected peers.
content: Living alone or being socially isolated may increase the risk for falls in older people, British researchers report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Depression in Childhood Tied to Physical Illnesses in Young Adulthood
description: Youths with depression had elevated risks of liver disease, thyroid illness and other problems in their 20s.
content: Children and adolescents diagnosed with depression may be at increased risk for physical diseases and premature death as young adults, researchers report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Big Tech Turns Its Lobbyists Loose on Europe, Alarming Regulators
description: Silicon Valley is building a powerful influence industry in Brussels, which has “never seen this kind of money” spent this way.
content: A leaked document jolted the European Union capital of Brussels in October, laying out in painstaking detail plans by Google to undermine new legislation that could severely damage its digital advertising business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Lidia Menapace, Who Fought Fascists and Sexists, Dies at 96
description: She was a partisan in northern Italy during World War II and denounced efforts to discount the role of women in the Resistance. She had been hospitalized with Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri, Melissa Kravitz Hoeffner, Nate Schweber and Alexandra E. Petri
title: N.Y.C. Restaurants Face Bleak Winter With No Indoor Dining
description: Restaurants already struggling during the pandemic are experiencing another setback. Many increasingly wonder how they will survive.
content: After being shut for two months in the spring because of the pandemic, Maria’s Bistro Mexicano in Sunset Park found signs of optimism in the summer. Outdoor dining bolstered sales. Laid-off workers were rehired. The dining room eventually reopened, welcoming dozens of customers every week to tables spaced six feet apart.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Dec. 14, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 14, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 14, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: Leave It in ‘Early Quar’?
description: As the U.S. prepares for a long, dark winter indoors, a look at some spring 2020 habits to revive, or avoid repeating.
content: As the United States braces for a long Covid winter, many people have been reflecting on the early spring, when the first wave of shutdowns transformed work, leisure and social life overnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: A Lim Kim Waited Out the Field to Win the U.S. Women’s Open
description: The South Korean golfer scanned anxious texts from home while waiting for challengers to finish the rain-delayed final round of the major championship.
content: HOUSTON — A Lim Kim ran into trouble after she birdied the final three holes for a three-under 67 that catapulted her to victory on Monday in the 75th United States Women’s Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Cleveland’s Baseball Team Will Drop Its Indians Team Name
description: The decision comes amid a wider push for sports teams to stop using Native American names and imagery as team names and mascots.
content: After years of protests from fans and Native American groups, the Cleveland Indians have decided to change their team name, moving away from a moniker that has long been criticized as racist, three people familiar with the decision said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery, Philip Cheung, Sylvia Jarrus, Dina Litovsky and Tristan Spinski
title: Silent Night: Scenes of a Pandemic Christmas
description: Photographers around the country captured how the pandemic has brought many hectic holiday traditions to a halt.
content: Every year, while braving the crowds and jammed parking lots at the mall, I vow that the next holiday season will be different: I’ll spend less time rushing and more time with my family. And yet, one harried holiday seems to blur with the next, like an annual form of amnesia set off by the sweet smell of freshly cut Christmas trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Wall Street Journal Opinion Editor Defends Item on Dr. Jill Biden
description: “There’s nothing like playing the race or gender card to stifle criticism,” Paul A. Gigot said as he accused Democrats of orchestrating a coordinated response to an op-ed piece.
content: The editorial page editor of The Wall Street Journal accused strategists for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. of instigating a coordinated response to an op-ed article published Friday evening that called on Jill Biden, Mr. Biden’s wife, to refrain from referring to herself as “Dr. Biden” because she is not a medical doctor, but rather holds a doctorate in education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Trump Has Never Believed in Democracy
description: He wants to wield power without winning it legitimately.
content: Donald Trump’s continued effort to overturn the result of the election — an effort buttressed by the support of many Republicans in Congress, it should be noted — is nothing short of an attempt at a bloodless coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Peyser
title: The People Who Actually Had a Pretty Great Year
description: It’s not just the filthy rich. Much of America’s professional class has quietly, if a bit guiltily, been doing just fine, despite 2020.
content: In late spring, after almost two months of pandemic-induced shutdown, Dr. Anita Kulkarni was finally allowed to reopen her plastic surgery practice near Dupont Circle in northwest Washington. “It was like I had opened a floodgate,” she said. “I had 40 appointments, Monday to Friday, 9 to 5. It was insane.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: For London, Tighter Virus Rules. For Boris Johnson, More Pressure.
description: The prime minister, already facing a tough week with Brexit, risks additional wrath from Conservatives over the closing of pubs and restaurants again.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson was already facing a treacherous week as he weighs whether to strike a Brexit trade deal with the European Union. Now, Mr. Johnson faces pressure on another front, after his government on Monday imposed tighter restrictions on London to curb a flare-up of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: The Crossword Stumper
description: A look at one of the entries that fooled solvers in last week’s puzzles.
content: STOP-TIME is a rhythmic device commonly used in early jazz. The accompanying instruments will play staccato accents (notes that have been cut short) while the soloist continues to play. This exaggerates the rhythm and highlights the soloist’s playing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Kevin Durant and Kyrie Irving Shine in Preseason Homecoming
description: With both players returning from injuries, Durant and Irving combined for 33 points in their first game together, more than a year after joining the Nets.
content: It’s rare that an N.B.A. preseason game is must-see television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump delays a plan to fast-track vaccines for White House staff members.
description: President Trump said on Sunday night that he would delay a plan for senior White House staff members to receive the coronavirus vaccine in the coming days.
content: President Trump said on Sunday night that he would delay a plan for senior White House staff members to receive the coronavirus vaccine in the coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: frippery
description: This word has appeared in nine articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Beethoven’s 250th Birthday: Here’s Everything You Need to Know
description: Explore the music, life and times of the composer who changed culture.
content: No composer left a mark on music quite like Ludwig van Beethoven. He took the popular forms of his time — symphony, string quartet, piano sonata, opera — and stretched them to their breaking points. He embodied the then-new ideal of the musician as passionate, politically engaged Romantic hero.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimberly dela Cruz and Mike Ives
title: Bicycling surges in Manila amid coronavirus lockdowns.
description: As the need for social distancing forces governments around the world to reduce public transportation service, city dwellers are hopping on bikes instead. Global bicycle sales have surged to the point where even Giant, the world’s largest bike maker, has struggled to fill orders.
content: As the need for social distancing forces governments around the world to reduce public transportation service, city dwellers are hopping on bikes instead. Global bicycle sales have surged to the point where even Giant, the world’s largest bike maker, has struggled to fill orders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: A recent surge in border crossings will test Biden’s promise to enact a more humane border policy.
description: After a steep decline in border crossings through much of this year, interceptions of unauthorized migrants are climbing again, setting the stage for the first significant challenge to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s pledge to adopt a more compassionate policy along America’s 1,100-mile border with Mexico.
content: After a steep decline in border crossings through much of this year, interceptions of unauthorized migrants are climbing again, setting the stage for the first significant challenge to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s pledge to adopt a more compassionate policy along America’s 1,100-mile border with Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: A TikTok Doctor Talks Vaccines
description: He brings the energy of popular short videos to cancer screenings and infection rates.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Autonomous Vehicles Take Another Big Leap
description: The Amazon-owned Zoox is unveiling an electric self-driving vehicle. But are we ready for driverless cars?
content: You know how to Google, how to Uber and how to Netflix and chill. Now, can Jeff Bezos get you to Zoox?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexa Weibel
title: 16 Delightful Cooking Projects to Brighten Up the Holidays
description: If you’ve got time on your hands, these recipes are a joy to make.
content: Unlike the frenzied holidays of seasons past, this one is quieter. With so many plans canceled and calendars cleared, escapist cooking can bring new holiday thrills for ambitious cooks. These festive, intricate recipes are a labor of love but a joy to create. Treat yourself while you have the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Cook Through This
description: These are hard times, and still, we’re here to say that cooking can help.
content: Good morning. How are you? It’s been nine months of this for a lot of us, and even if the vaccine news is good, it’s not like we’ll be crowding into Katz’s for pastrami any time soon. We’re exhausted. We’re exhausted by so much: anxiety, grief, employment worries, childcare issues, food insecurity, general uneasiness about the state of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Why This Force of 150 Sheriff’s Deputies Is Enforcing Virus Rules
description: The New York City Sheriff’s Office, a law enforcement team unknown to most New Yorkers, has been thrust into the spotlight during the pandemic.
content: When it came time to crack down on Mac’s Public House, the Staten Island bar that has notoriously defied Covid-19 restrictions, the city sent in a law enforcement team in familiar blue officers’ uniforms wearing badges and carrying guns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Ian Austen
title: Canada and the Coronavirus Vaccine: Here’s What It Means
description: Who gets its first? Is it safe? And just how soon will life return to normal? As Canada vaccinates its first citizens, here are answers to some common questions.
content: Canada on Monday joined Britain and the United States as the first Western nations to start inoculating their citizens against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: How Selfish Are Plants? Let’s Do Some Root Analysis
description: A new model further untangles the complex strategy games playing out under our feet.
content: Imagine you’re a pepper plant. You need water and nutrients. Luckily, you can grow roots that grab that stuff from the soil and pipe it back to you. So far, so good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: No, Republican attempts to organize ‘alternate’ electors won’t affect the official Electoral College tally.
description: Try as they might, the Republicans in Georgia and Michigan who organized uncertified shadow electors to cast votes for President Trump will not be succeeding in their attempt to change their states’ Electoral College votes.
content: Try as they might, the Republicans in Georgia and Michigan who organized uncertified shadow electors to cast votes for President Trump will not be succeeding in their attempt to change their states’ Electoral College votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: Schools Will Close in Germany as Cases Surge
description: Even in a country once seen as a success story, the second wave is taking a toll on education
content: This fall, even as cases surged across Europe, Germany worked hard to keep schools open, prioritizing them over other aspects of daily life like restaurants and bars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Beethoven’s 250th Birthday: His Greatness Is in the Details
description: Brahms, Wagner, even Sondheim: All have followed the great master in building their works from small bits of music.
content: The classical music industry had planned to go all out commemorating Beethoven’s 250th anniversary this year, culminating in his birthday this week. As it happens, the precise date of his birth is uncertain. Records indicate that he was baptized in Bonn, Germany, on Dec. 17, 1770. Since it was customary then to carry out that ritual within 24 hours of a birth, it’s been assumed he was born on Dec. 16 — but we don’t know for sure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Wilkinson
title: A Hotel That Pays Tribute to Rajasthani Arts and Crafts
description: Located in Jaipur’s jewelry district, where fine stones are sold alongside sweets and produce, the Johri shines as bright as any gem.
content: A stone’s throw from the lines of veteran vendors selling sweets, fresh vegetables and gems for fine jewelry at the famous Johri Bazaar in Jaipur’s walled Old City sits a hulking late 19th-century limestone building with a terra cotta-colored facade. For decades, it operated as a single-family home owned by a branch of the Kasliwal family, members of which have made jewelry for maharajahs, kings and queens since the 16th century and whose business, Gem Palace, is now run by the ninth-generation jeweler and entrepreneur Siddharth Kasliwal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Days After Reopening, London Theaters Must Shut
description: The musical “Six” and a concert version of “Les Miserables” are among the shows that will close because of rising coronavirus cases in the city.
content: LONDON — On Dec. 5, “Six” — the hit show about the wives of Henry VIII — staged a triumphant comeback when it became the first musical to be staged in London’s West End since the coronavirus pandemic began in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein
title: Electoral College Voter: Long an Honor, and Now Also a Headache
description: Casting votes in the Electoral College has been a routine part of election mechanics, but this year electors have been thrust into the cross hairs of President Trump’s extraordinary effort to overturn the results.
content: In Michigan, Democratic electors have been promised police escorts from their cars into the State Capitol, where on Monday they will formally vote for Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: Fruit Flies Are Essential to Science. So Are the Workers Who Keep Them Alive.
description: Sustaining the world’s biggest Drosophila collection during the pandemic has been a challenge, but the people in Indiana who supply the insects to labs around the world stay dedicated to the task.
content: The rooms that make up the Bloomington Drosophila Stock Center at Indiana University are lined wall to wall with identical shelves. Each shelf is filled with uniform racks, and each rack with indistinguishable glass vials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Cleveland Makes Name Removal Official, Saying It Is ‘Moving Forward’
description: The baseball team’s process is being lauded by many rights groups for its thoughtful reconsideration of the name “Indians.”
content: Over the summer, while the country was still roiled by protests over the death of George Floyd at the hands of the police, the Cleveland Indians began to investigate a name change. The team had been known as the Indians since 1915, but after years of protest and criticism over a name that was deemed by many to be racist, it said the time was right to determine whether the name was still appropriate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Sarah Hughes
title: Vaccines, Electoral College, Google: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: California’s electors are meeting now. Their votes are expected to push Biden over the top.
description: California’s 55 electors are meeting now as they prepare to cast their votes for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: California’s 55 electors are meeting now as they prepare to cast their votes for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: The Electoral College Meets
description: An archaic institution finds itself in the spotlight: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: The Electoral College will vote today, but protesters from coast to coast are still unwilling to accept the election’s results. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark C. Taylor
title: A.I. and I
description: Artificial intelligence has given my pancreas a mind of its own. Am I the human being of the future?
content: Artificial intelligence often scares us. If you think going for a ride in a self-driving car requires a leap of faith, try having your life depend on an autonomous pancreas hitched to your belt whose algorithms are, for you, the difference between life and death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: ‘I Trust Science,’ Says Nurse Who Is First to Get Vaccine in U.S.
description: Sandra Lindsay, a nurse at a Queens hospital, was the first person in the United States to be vaccinated. She wanted to “inspire people who look like me.”
content: When officials at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center asked for staff volunteers to be among the first to take the coronavirus vaccine, Sandra Lindsay raised her hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Nicholas Fandos
title: President Trump still shows no sign he will concede.
description: Despite recently suffering the most consequential in a string of defeats in his quest to subvert the results of November’s election, President Trump continued to insist over the weekend that his plans to challenge his loss were “not over.”
content: Despite recently suffering the most consequential in a string of defeats in his quest to subvert the results of November’s election, President Trump continued to insist over the weekend that his plans to challenge his loss were “not over.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Donald Trump Lost His Battle. The Culture War Goes On.
description: The reality-TV president was a practitioner, and a product, of a style of pop-cultural grievance that will outlast him.
content: You could say that the Trump presidency effectively ended when the polls closed election night or when news outlets called the contest for Joseph R. Biden Jr. four days later. You could say that it ended when the Electoral College voted on Monday to make Mr. Biden the president, or that it will end when Mr. Biden is sworn in on Jan. 20.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Improving Your Balance to Prevent Falls
description: Balance is something the body learns to do automatically by engaging the postural muscles.
content: Several times a day, whether I’m indoors or out, my bone doctor’s mantra reverberates in my head: “Do Not Fall!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Russian Officers Were Near Navalny When He Was Poisoned, Report Says
description: The agents, from a unit with poisonous chemicals expertise, were tracked by their telephones, the Bellingcat investigative group said, the strongest evidence of Moscow’s involvement in the nerve agent attack.
content: Officers from a secret Russian spy unit with expertise in poisonous substances trailed the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny for years and were nearby at the time he was exposed to a highly toxic nerve agent that almost killed him last summer, according to a report by Bellingcat, a research group that specializes in open-source investigations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: An Agent’s Mistake Cost an N.B.A. Player $3 Million. He Paid Him Back.
description: All Bill Duffy had to do was inform the Miami Heat that Anthony Carter planned to return. Two decades after failing to do that, Duffy has made his client whole.
content: Anthony Carter is one of the most consequential figures in Miami Heat history. And it was all because of a mistake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: What Country Music Asked of Charley Pride
description: The singer put himself on the line to become the genre’s first Black superstar. He died on Saturday not long after performing at a largely mask-free awards ceremony.
content: At the 54th annual Country Music Association Awards last month, there was Charley Pride, onstage singing his indelible 1971 hit “Kiss an Angel Good Mornin’” alongside the rising country star Jimmie Allen. In the socially distanced audience, Nashville luminaries took in the wondrous spectacle. Eric Church, exuding stoic cool — no mask. Brothers Osborne singing along — no masks. Ashley McBryde swaying to the music — no mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Firewood Holders
description: If you have a working fireplace, it’s time to stock up on wood. And you’ll need somewhere to put it.
content: If you’re lucky enough to have a wood-burning fireplace, you can look forward to one of winter’s most enjoyable activities: spending cozy nights around the hearth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Early voting begins in the Georgia runoffs, which will determine control of the Senate.
description: For weeks, the runoff races for Georgia’s two Senate seats have virtually been impossible for residents to escape, as campaign coverage has dominated the local news and advertisements praising or attacking the candidates have filled every commercial break.
content: For weeks, the runoff races for Georgia’s two Senate seats have virtually been impossible for residents to escape, as campaign coverage has dominated the local news and advertisements praising or attacking the candidates have filled every commercial break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: CNN and MSNBC Fret Over Post-Trump Future
description: Ratings have hit new highs, but executives and journalists at both networks are uneasy about the year ahead.
content: CNN and MSNBC thrived during the Trump years, reaching new heights in ratings and revenue while devoting countless prime-time hours to criticizing a White House antagonist their viewers just could not quit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on 2 Iranian Officials in Robert Levinson Case
description: The Treasury imposed sanctions on two Interior Ministry officials, who it said were “involved in the abduction, detention and probable death” of Mr. Levinson, a former F.B.I. agent.
content: The Trump administration announced sanctions on two Iranian officials for their involvement in the 2007 disappearance and presumed death of the former F.B.I. agent Robert Levinson, the first time the U.S. government has officially implicated Iran’s government in Mr. Levinson’s case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: Stephen King Has Thoughts About Stephen King TV Shows
description: With a new adaptation of “The Stand” arriving Thursday on CBS All Access, the best-selling author looked back at the best and worst adaptations of his stories for television.
content: Stephen King has written some of the most beloved horror novels in the history of popular fiction, and many have been turned into equally acclaimed and successful films. Movies like “Carrie,” “Stand by Me” and “The Shawshank Redemption” have more than earned esteemed spots within the cinematic canon. Others — “Maximum Overdrive,” “Thinner,” “The Dark Tower” — have not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter
title: What Happens to the Unemployed When the Checks Run Out
description: Millions face a steep and immediate drop in spending power when federal jobless benefits end this month, with a sharp rise in the poverty rate.
content: When jobless workers get their last unemployment check, the effect on spending is sharp and swift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Stanford’s Tara VanDerveer Ties Record for Coaching Wins
description: VanDerveer can pass Pat Summitt, the longtime Tennessee coach who died in 2016, on Tuesday against Pacific.
content: Tara VanDerveer tied Pat Summitt for the most career coaching wins in Division I women’s college basketball on Sunday night when top-ranked Stanford trounced its rival California, 83-38, in Berkeley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘The Dark Knight’ and ‘The Blues Brothers’ Join National Film Registry
description: The movies, along with “A Clockwork Orange” and “Sweet Sweetback’s Baadasssss Song,” are among 25 selected by the Library of Congress.
content: As the oft-quoted line from “The Dark Knight” goes, “You either die a hero or you live long enough to see yourself become the villain.” Now a more respectable immortality awaits this 2008 Christopher Nolan superhero blockbuster, which earned Heath Ledger a posthumous Academy Award for his performance as the Joker: it is among the memorable motion pictures, along with “Shrek,” “A Clockwork Orange” and “Sweet Sweetback’s Baadasssss Song,” that have been chosen for preservation this year on the Library of Congress’s National Film Registry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Answers to Your Questions About the New Covid Vaccines in the U.S.
description: Vaccines are rolling out to health workers now and will reach the arms of the rest of us by spring. Here’s what you need to know.
content: There aren’t enough doses for everyone, so initially the vaccine will be rationed for those who need it most. It will take time to produce and distribute the vaccine, and then schedule two vaccinations per person, three to four weeks apart. As more vaccines get approved, things will speed up. At least 40 million doses (enough for 20 million people) should be available from Pfizer and Moderna by the end of the year, and much more will come in 2021. How many doses will your state get? Look up your state’s vaccine distribution plans here. —Abby Goodnough
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño, Manuela Andreoni and Letícia Casado
title: ‘Playing With Lives’: Brazil’s Covid Vaccine Plan Is Mired in Chaos
description: Political infighting, haphazard planning and a rising anti-vaccine movement have turned the country into a cautionary tale in the coronavirus era.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — As countries rushed their preparations to inoculate citizens against the coronavirus, Brazil, with its world-renowned immunization program and a robust pharmaceutical manufacturing capacity, should have been at a significant advantage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: The Cleveland Biebers? A Baseball Team Is in Need of a Name
description: As fans speculate what name Cleveland will choose to replace “Indians,” the team’s past presents some fairly odd options.
content: Baseball teams have been named for animals, local landmarks and a brand of handgun. Several of them have been identified by the color of their socks. There is one named after a mountain range and another that references dodging the trolleys of a city the team left more than 60 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruchir Sharma
title: Pound for Pound, Taiwan Is the Most Important Place in the World
description: Its excellence in the computer chip market puts it at the center of the battle for global technological supremacy.
content: The Cold War between the United States and the Soviet Union perpetually threatened to spark conflict in nations all over the world, including battles over the control of a vast array of natural and industrial resources. The new Cold War, between the United States and China, is increasingly focused on access to just one industry in one place: computer chips made in Taiwan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Peragine
title: In Iowa, an emergency room nurse is first in line for vaccination.
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa — The vaccine arrived at the University of Iowa Hospital at 7:30 a.m. in a refrigerated FedEx truck, and it was not long before the first dose was injected into the arm of David Conway, 39, an emergency-room nurse.
content: IOWA CITY, Iowa — The vaccine arrived at the University of Iowa Hospital at 7:30 a.m. in a refrigerated FedEx truck, and it was not long before the first dose was injected into the arm of David Conway, 39, an emergency-room nurse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Pasick and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Vaccinations Begin in the U.S.
description: A moment of hope, as the country passes another tragic milestone.
content: Today an array of frontline health care workers received the first doses of a mass vaccination campaign that could bring an end to the coronavirus pandemic in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Shawn Mendes Hits No. 1 for the Fourth Time
description: The pop-rock singer and songwriter’s latest album, “Wonder,” debuted at the top a week before Taylor Swift’s surprise “Evermore” arrives on the chart.
content: Five years ago, Shawn Mendes was a fresh-faced 11th-grader from Pickering, Ontario, who had ridden a wave of six-second videos on the defunct app Vine — the proto-TikTok — into a surprise No. 1 debut album.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Wisconsin’s Supreme Court denies a last-ditch Trump effort to toss 200,000 votes from Milwaukee and Madison.
description: The Wisconsin Supreme Court on Monday denied President Trump’s attempt to invalidate more than 200,000 votes in the state’s two biggest Democratic bastions for the second time this month.
content: The Wisconsin Supreme Court on Monday denied President Trump’s attempt to invalidate more than 200,000 votes in the state’s two biggest Democratic bastions for the second time this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Restaurants Forge Ahead Without Indoor Dining
description: The second wave of the coronavirus has brought a new hardship for  restaurants, which now confront a winter with no indoor dining.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: The U.S. rolls out vaccines.
content: The first shots were given in the American mass vaccination campaign on Monday morning, opening a new chapter in the battle against the coronavirus pandemic, which has killed more people in the U.S. than in any other country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Google’s apps crash in a worldwide outage.
description: The tech giant’s popular services like Gmail, Hangouts, Meet and YouTube went offline, halting work across the globe.
content: Internet users worldwide received a jarring reminder on Monday about just how reliant they were on Google, when the Silicon Valley giant suffered a major outage for about an hour, sending many of its most popular services offline.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Georgia’s Secretary of State on Standing Up to Trump
description: Georgia’s secretary of state infuriated Donald Trump when he stood by Georgia’s presidential election results. Now he has the critical task of overseeing two U.S. Senate runoffs that will determine the fate of the nation.
content: Georgia begins early voting today in two runoffs that will decide the composition of the next U.S. Senate. If Democrats win both seats, the Senate will be split 50-50 (with Vice President-elect Kamala Harris acting as tiebreaker). If they don’t, it will be controlled by Republicans who stand ready to block many actions of a Biden presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Big Day in the U.S.
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: The members of the Electoral College will meet in states across the country today. And while President Trump has tried to disrupt the process, his chances of succeeding remain very slim.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Struggling Restaurants Face Bleak Future as Indoor Dining Ban Begins
